112495 S2468-8231(22)00381-9 10.1016/j.mcat.2022.112495 Scheme 1 Synthesis of {ZNN}CrCl2(THF) complexes. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 Ground state optimized structures of Cr2 and Cr4 at the BP86/def2-TZVP level of theory. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Topographic steric maps of the pyrrolide-imine with pendant O- and N-donor groups in Cr1/Cr3 and Cr6/Cr7. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Influence of the nature of chromium precatalyst Cr1-Cr7 on TOF and distribution of products ([Cr] = 10μmol, T = 80 °C, 20 bar, time = 15 min, [Al]/[Cr] = 300). Fig 3 Fig. 4 Oligomers distribution produced by Cr1-Cr7/MAO oligomerization systems (C4-C10) (80 °C, 20 bar, [Al/[Cr] = 500). (a) Schulz−Flory α-olefin distribution as mol % (n) vs carbon number and (b) plot of the log(mol%) of vs carbon number. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Selectivity of Cr1-Cr7/MAO oligomerization systems for α‐olefins (T = 80 °C, 20 bar, time = 15 min, [Al]/[Cr] = 500). Fig 5 Fig. 6 Monitoring of selectivities and productivities as a function of time in the ethylene oligomerization reaction promoted by the Cr2/MAO system (T = 80 °C, 20 bar of ethylene, [Al]/[Cr] = 500). Fig 6 Fig. 7 3D representations of key intermediates for Cr4/MAO catalyst system under ethylene atmosphere at the BP86/def2-TZVP level of theory with the SMD solvation model and toluene as the solvent. Fig 7 Scheme 2 Proposed mechanism for generation of the cationic dinuclear Cr (III) species from activation of Cr2 with MAO. Scheme 2 Fig. 8 Optimized structure for dinuclear species Cr2-C at the BP86/def2-TZVP level of theory. Geometry optimization was performed in the absence of an anion. Oligo- and polymerization of ethylene by pyrrolide-imine chromium catalysts bearing pendant O-, S- and N-donor groups. Synthesis, characterization and DFT studies Sabrina M. da Silva a Adriana C. Pinheiro b Miriã T. da Costa a Thiago C.G. Alves b Robson S. Oliboni b Rafael Stieler a Adriana C.A. Casagrande a O.L. Casagrande Jr a ⁎ a Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis, Instituto de Química, Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Avenida Bento Gonçalves, 9500, 90501-970 Porto Alegre, RS, Brazil Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis Instituto de Química Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul Avenida Bento Gonçalves, 9500 Porto Alegre RS 90501-970 Brazil aLaboratory of Molecular Catalysis, Instituto de Química, Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Avenida Bento Gonçalves, 9500, 90501-970, Porto Alegre, RS, Brazil b Grupo de Catálise e Estudos Teóricos, Centro de Ciências Químicas, Farmacêuticas e de Alimentos – CCQFA, Universidade Federal de Pelotas, 96010-900, Pelotas, RS, Brazil Grupo de Catálise e Estudos Teóricos Centro de Ciências Químicas, Farmacêuticas e de Alimentos – CCQFA Universidade Federal de Pelotas Pelotas RS 96010-900 Brazil bGrupo de Catálise e Estudos Teóricos, Centro de Ciências Químicas, Farmacêuticas e de Alimentos – CCQFA, Universidade Federal de Pelotas, 96010-900, Pelotas, RS, Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. The synthesis and ethylene reactivity of a new set of chromium(III) complexes supported by pyrrolide-imine ligands bearing pendant O-, S- and N-donor groups [Cr{(C4H3N-2-CH=N)Z}(THF)Cl2] (Z = CH2Ph-2-OMe, Cr1; Z = Ph-2-OPh, Cr2; Z = Ph-2-OMe, Cr3; Z = Ph-2-SPh, Cr4; Z = Ph-2-SMe, Cr5; Z = CH2Py, Cr6; Z = C2H4Py, Cr7) are described. Activation of Cr1-Cr7 with MAO generates active systems affording a full range oligomerization of ethylene (C4-C12 +) with turnover frequencies (TOFs) in the range of 13,900–94,200 mol(ethylene)·mol(Cr)–1·h–1 along with production of a varied amount of polymer (6.9 - 91.5 wt.%). The nature of the pendant group has a significant impact on the catalytic performances of these Cr complexes. Particularly, catalytic precursors containing pendant O-donor groups (Cr1-Cr3) produce mostly oligomers (up to 89.0 wt%) while those bearing sulfur-base donor groups (Cr4 and Cr5) are primarily polymerization systems. DFT calculations suggested the presence of two different CrIII catalytic species, the mononuclear species responsible for production of polymer and one dinuclear species that have been ascribed for production of oligomers. By tunning the reactional conditions, higher TOF and higher selectivities for production of α-olefins were achieved. Notably, the use of high MAO loading (1500 equiv.) enhanced the activity of Cr2 [TOF = 389,800 (mol ethylene)⋅(mol Cr)−1⋅h−1] producing mostly oligomers (97.7 wt% of total products) with high selectivity for α-olefins (>95.5 wt.%). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Chromium(III) complexes Pyrrolide-imine ligands Ethylene oligomerization Ethylene polymerization DFT studies Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The development of new homogeneous transition-metal-based catalysts for the oligomerization of ethylene has attracted considerable interest over the past decades, to achieve highly active and selective systems towards production of linear α-olefins (LAOs). These LAOs have long been a topic of considerable interest within both industry and academia due to their importance for preparing a large number of end products such as linear low-density polyethylene (LLDPE), plasticizers, surfactants for detergents, base stock, additives for synthetic lubricants, and alcohols for plasticizers [1–4]. Several available commercial technologies (Chevron-Phillips, Shell, IFP/Sabic Alphabutol®, Ineos, Sabic/Linde and Alpha-SABLIN®) are dedicated to produce LAOs with carbon chain lengths varying from C4 to C20 [5–9]. More recently, companies such as CPChem and Sasol have introduced the tri/tetramerization processes for the selectively production of 1-hexene and 1-octene [10–11]. Among all classes of olefin oligomerization catalysts, chromium complexes are, by far, the most studied systems for selective and nonselective ethylene oligomerization processes [6, 12-26]. In particular, chromium-based metal catalysts containing Schiff base ligands have been successfully used in oligo- and polymerization of ethylene thanks to the easy preparation and tunable steric and electronic properties of this class of ligands [21, 27-36]. Usually, these catalysts produce a Schulz–Flory distribution of oligomers along with a variable amount of polymers or waxes. Such behavior might be associated to the rapid interchange, under operando conditions, of the mono-, di-, and trivalent oxidation states as well as the nuclearity of the catalytic species as already observed for other catalytic system based on chromium compounds [16, 37-42]. Thus, despite the advances in the use of these chromium complexes in ethylene oligomerization, major challenges related to the selectivity and product distribution (oligomers vs polymers) need to be overcome. In this context, great efforts have been made to develop new classes of Schiff base ligands containing a variety of donor groups aiming to improve the catalytic performance of chromium catalysts towards the selective production of lighter olefins such as 1-C6 and -C8. Previous works from our group have focused on the synthesis and catalytic performance of chromium complexes containing bi- and tridentate Schiff bases [21, 28, 29, 34, 36]. We recently communicated on tridentate pyrrolide-imino-amine/ether complexes of Cr(III), which the steric effects in the pyrrole moiety play a pronounced role in controlling the oligomer/PE ratio while tuning of electronic effects, using either a phenylamine or a phenoxy unit, has a higher impact on the catalytic activity [36]. Based on these results, we decided to expand this class of chromium complexes varying the nature of the pendant donor group, and see how the steric and electronic effects from these linked donor arms could influence the catalytic performance of these catalysts. Herein, we report the synthesis and characterization of a new set of pyrrolide-imine chromium(III) complexes bearing the pendant O-, S- and N-donor group and their use as catalysts for oligo- and polymerization of ethylene. The present study shows the significant impact that the nature of the pendant group has on the product distribution (oligomers vs polymers). Furthermore, this paper will discuss the oligomerization results, evaluating the influence of the experimental parameters on the activity, selectivity, and product distribution. 2 Experimental 2.1 General methods All manipulations involving air- and/or moisture-sensitive compounds were carried out in an MBraun glovebox or under dry argon using standard Schlenk techniques. Toluene, THF, and hexane were dried over a Braun MB-SPS-800 solvent purification system. Other solvents were dried from the appropriate drying agents under argon before use. CrCl3(THF)3 was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. The pyrrole-imine ligands (L1-L7) were prepared by following the literature procedures [43–46]. Ethylene (White Martins Co.) and argon were deoxygenated and dried through BTS columns (BASF) and 3 Å activated molecular sieves prior to use. MAO (Witco, 5.21 wt.% Al solution in toluene, 20 % TMA), triisobutylaluminum (TIBA) (Sigma-Aldrich, 1 M in hexane) and trimethylaluminum (TMA) (Sigma-Aldrich, 2 M in toluene) were used as received. Infrared spectra were performed on neat products using a FT-IR Bruker Alpha Spectrometer operating in the ATR mode. NMR spectra of the ligands were recorded on a Varian MR-400 spectrometer. 1H and 13C NMR chemical shifts are reported in ppm vs. SiMe4 and were determined by reference to the residual solvent peaks. Elemental analyses were performed by the Analytical Central Service of the Institute of Chemistry-UFRGS (Brazil) and are the average of two independent determinations. Magnetic moment data were obtained on a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS magnetometer, operating with a constant magnetic field of 1000 Oe. High-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) data were collected on a Micromass Waters® Q-Tof spectrometer. Quantitative gas chromatographic analysis of ethylene oligomerization products was performed on a Agilent 7890A instrument equipped with a Petrocol HD capillary column (methyl silicone, 100 m length, 0.25 mm i.d. and film thickness of 0.5 μm) (36 °C for 15 min, then heating at 5 °C⋅min−1 until 250 °C); cyclohexane was used as internal standard. Polymer melting points were measured by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) with a TA DSC Q20 using a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 after twice previous heating to 180 °C and cooling to 40 °C at 10 °C min−1. 2.2 Synthesis of chromium complexes 2.2.1 [Cr{(C4H3N-2-CH=N)CH2Ph-2-OMe}(THF)Cl2] (Cr1) To a stirred solution of L1 (0.100 g, 0.46 mmol) in THF (5 mL), a solution of KH (0.020 g, 0.51 mmol) in THF (10 mL) at -30 °C was added dropwise. The resulting solution was stirred for 3 h at room temperature, then filtered by cannula. The resulting red-brown mixture was then added dropwise over a period of 15 minutes to a solution of [CrCl3(THF)3] (0.162 g, 0.46 mmol) in THF (10 mL) at -30 °C under constant stirring. The reaction mixture was stirred overnight at room temperature. The resulting solution was filtered by cannula to remove the byproduct, potassium chloride (KCl), which was present as a thin solid. The resulting solution was concentrated (3 mL) and hexane (15 mL) was added to form a precipitate. The resulting product (Cr1), a light brown solid (0.162 g, 85%), was washed with hexane (2×10 mL) and dried for 24 hours in vacuo. Found: 285.0350 [M-THF-Cl]+. 2.3 General oligomerization procedure Ethylene oligomerization reactions were performed in a 100 mL double-walled stainless Parr reactor equipped with mechanical stirring, internal temperature control and continuous feed of ethylene. The Parr reactor was dried in an oven at 120 °C for 5 h prior to each run, and then cooled under vacuum for 30 min. A typical reaction was performed by introducing toluene (30 mL) and the proper amount of cocatalyst into the reactor under an ethylene atmosphere. After 20 min, the toluene catalyst solution (10 mL, [Cr] = 10 μmol) was injected into the reactor under a stream of ethylene and then the reactor was immediately pressurized. Ethylene was continuously fed in order to maintain the desired ethylene pressure. After 15 min, the reaction was stopped by cooling the system to -60 °C and depressurizing. An exact amount of cyclohexane was introduced (as an internal standard) and the mixture was analyzed by quantitative GLC. The polymer was separated by filtration, washed with small portions of acidic ethanol, then ethanol and water, and the resulting material was dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 12 h. 2.4 Computational details All simulations were performed with the ORCA 4.2 package [47] with the BP86 functional [48–49] and def2-TVZP basis set. [50] The RIJCOSX approximation[51], the def2/J auxiliary basis [52] and the D3BJ dispersion correction [53] were used throughout all calculations. All optimized structures were confirmed as minima as no imaginary frequencies were found. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of chromium complexes The chromium(III) dichloride complexes Cr1-Cr7 were isolated in moderate to good yields from the reaction between CrCl3(THF)3 and potassium salts of pyrrolide-imine ligands L1-L7 in THF. (Scheme 1 ). All complexes are air- and moisture-sensitive, and show moderate solubility at room temperature in acetonitrile, dichloromethane and THF. The elemental analysis and ESI-HRMS results agree with the formation of the desired product associated to the coordination of one THF molecule as similarly found in the analogous Cr compounds [36]. The magnetic moments measured (μ eff) for Cr1 (2.95 μ B) and Cr4 (3.78 μ B) are consistent with an octahedral, high-spin chromium(III) environment [54–57]. Unfortunately, attempts to recrystallize the precatalysts Cr1-Cr7 using several crystallization procedures failed, resulting in a mixture of amorphous materials/decomposed products that were not suitable for a single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction analysis. Thus, we conducted DFT calculations in order to obtain information on the structures of the Cr1-Cr7 precatalysts (see SI for detailed structural parameters). All chromium complexes exhibited a slightly distorted octahedral geometries with pyrrolide-imine ligands coordinated to the metal center in a tridentate meridional fashion, and two chloride ligands occupying mutually trans positions, and in a rather good agreement with the experimental structural data of similar chromium compounds [36]. Some selected geometrical parameters are summarized in Table S1. Optimized structures for the ground state obtained at the BP86/def2-TZVP level of theory for Cr2 and Cr4 are shown in Fig. 1 . The Cr-Nimine [1.972–2.023 Å], Cr-Npyr [1.972–2.022 Å], and Cr-Clav [2.298–2.315 Å] bond distances are comparable in magnitude with related chromium structures reported in the literature [41, 58-60]. As expected, the Cr-O bond distances for Cr1-Cr3 (average of 2.172 Å) are shorter than Cr-S distances in Cr4 and Cr5 (average of 2.465 Å) considering the larger atomic radius of S atom. However, there are no significant differences in the coordination sphere of Cr2/Cr4 and Cr3/Cr5 when oxygen is changed by sulfur atom (Figs. S5 and S6). When the length of the spacer between the central imine and the O- or N-donor group was increased by one carbon (compare Cr1/Cr3 and Cr6/Cr7), the Cr-X bond distances (X = O, N) as well as chelate bite angles increased due to the formation of 6-membered ring systems. (Fig. S6). Furthermore, the expansion of chelate ring in Cr1 and Cr7 led to a higher percent buried volume (%V Bur) [61] with respect to Cr3 and Cr6 that can be beneficial for the protection of the chromium metal center, and thus improving the TOF'S of these precatalysts (Fig. 2 ). For instance, the activities of Cr1 and Cr7 is Ca of 35% higher than Cr3 and Cr6. 3.2 Ethylene oligo- and polymerization studies Chromium precatalysts Cr1-Cr7 were evaluated in oligo- and polymerization of ethylene at 80 °C, 20 bar constant ethylene pressure, and using methylaluminoxane (MAO) as cocatalyst. Table 1 summarizes the results of reactions carried out using 10 μmol of precatalyst in 40 mL of toluene. All oligomerization runs were at least duplicated with the error (activity and product selectivity) estimated to be around ±10%. Upon activation with MAO, the chromium complexes Cr1-Cr7 generated active systems affording a full range oligomerization of ethylene (C4-C12+) with turnover frequencies (TOFs) in the range of 13,900–94,200 mol(ethylene)·mol(Cr)–1·h–1 along with production of a varied amount of polymer (6.9 - 91.4 wt.%). As presented in Fig. 3 , the electronic nature of the R group at the pendant O- and S-donor moieties has a significant impact on the catalytic performances of these Cr complexes. Hence, Cr2 and Cr4 containing an electron-withdrawing substituent (i.e., phenyl) showed higher productivities in comparison to those bearing electron-donating group (i.e., methyl) (Cr3 and Cr5). These results suggest that the introduction of electron-withdrawing group on the pendant O- and S-donor moieties may enhance the Lewis acidity at the chromium metal center, and thus making easier the coordination of ethylene to the metal center. The oligomer/polymer ratio is strongly dependent on the donor atom (O, S). While catalytic precursors containing pendant O-donor groups (Cr1-Cr3) produce mostly oligomers (up to 89.0 wt%), those ones based on sulfur-donor groups (Cr4 and Cr5) produced almost exclusively polymers (91.0 wt%) with catalytic activities of 4013 and 5447 kg of PE mol(Cr)–1⋅h–1, respectively. One can speculate here that the donor atom is influencing the nature of the catalytically active species. Thus, we assume that pyrrolide-imine ligands bearing O-donor groups afford more stable active species for production of oligomers, while those ones containing S-donor groups generate primarily polymerization active species. The use of pyridine (Cr6 and Cr7) as the pendant donor group yielded a full range oligomerization of ethylene (C4-C12 +) along with the production of a substantial amount of polymer (26.1 – 31.8 wt%) suggesting that besides the catalytic species for production of oligomers, a stable polymerization species is also operative in the catalytic system. It is interesting to note that the extension of the pendant group by introducing a methylene unit positively affected the catalytic performance of Cr1 and Cr7 as compared to Cr3 and Cr6. This result can be rationalized to the formation of less strained 6-membered-ring chromium complexes, thus generating a more stable catalytic species as discussed earlier. Particularly, the highest activity among the precatalysts screened was reached with Cr7 [TOF = 94,200 mol(ethylene) mol(Cr)–1·h–1]. These results presented above showed that the pendant O-, S or N-donor groups have significant influence on the catalytic behavior of the catalyst precursors suggesting that the third donor group at the pyrrolide-imine ligand is influencing the nature of the active species (oxidation state of the metal center and nuclearity) as well as mechanistic features involved in the oligomerization of ethylene. These results are in line with those found for other catalytic systems based on chromium complexes bearing bi- and tridentate ligands. For instance, Liu and coworkers investigated in detail the ethylene co-oligomerization mechanisms for a cationic chromium-PNPOMe system using the density functional theory (DFT) method. [62] The DFT calculations corroborated with the metallacycle mechanism for ethylene trimerization through several chromacycloheptane intermediates. Additionally, it has been shown that the pendant methoxy unit coordinates to the chromium metal center, which is significant role in the 1-hexene selectivity. More recently, Bischof, Ess and co-workers performed the DFT calculations to examine the difference between the highly reactive bidentate (P,N)Cr and unreactive tridentate (P,N,P)Cr catalysts for ethylene trimerization[63]. They found that for the (P,N)Cr catalyst, there are multiple CrI ethylene-coordinated resting states and multiple turnover frequency (TOF)-controlling transition states. In contrast, and a rationale for slower reactivity, the (P,N,N)Cr catalyst has a stabilized chromacyclopentane resting state. Chromium precatalysts Cr1-Cr3, Cr6 and Cr7 led to a full range oligomerization of ethylene (from C4 to C12 +) following a Schulz–Flory distribution with the K values varying from 0.83 to 0.88. (Fig. 4 ). In general, it was observed that butenes is the largest component in the liquid fraction suggesting that under this class of precatalysts operates via a Cossee-Arlman mechanism. The higher K values calculated for Cr4 (1.01) and Cr5 (0.97) are associated the more uniform distribution of oligomer in the range of C4-C10. As can be visualized in Fig. 5 , the selectivities within the liquid fraction are also influenced by the nature of the pendant donor group. Among the precatalysts bearing pendant O-donor groups, enriched fractions in C6 (27.5 mol %) and C8 (18.6 mol %) is obtained using Cr3 while the 6-membered-ring chromium precatalyst Cr1 is more prone to produce higher amount of 1-butene (33.1 mol%). As expected, the distribution of oligomer in the liquid fraction for the chromium complexes containing pendant S-donor groups are centered on heavier olefins fractions [C10 + C12 + (Cr4: 63.5 mol%; Cr5: 66.3 mol%)]. Overall, the activities observed for this class of chromium precatalysts are slightly higher than similar MAO-activated chromium complexes containing pyrrolide-imine ligands [46]. Furthermore, these precatalysts afford a more balanced distribution of lighter α-olefins along with production of much lower amounts of 1-butene (13.4 -19.3 wt%) and higher amounts of α-C8 (16.9–21.1 wt%) (Table 1, entries 1–3, 6 and 7) as compared to those ones reported previously [46]. The polymers obtained by Cr1-Cr7 showed several broad peaks in the range of 65.4–125.8 °C suggesting the production of linear oligoethylenes (Figs. S9–15). The DSC data are in agreement with those found for other chromium complexes bearing bi- and tridentate ligands [43, 64-66]. Besides, the NMR results for the polymers produced by Cr1 and Cr7 revealed the formation of linear oligomers with vinyl end-groups, and lower Mn values lower than 1600 g·mol–1 (Figs. S16-S19). In order to evaluate the influence of reaction conditions on the activity, selectivity and distribution of products (oligomers vs polymer), a series of oligomerization reactions were performed using Cr2/MAO varying some oligomerization parameters such as the MAO loading, cocatalyst type, run time, ethylene pressure and temperature. The [Al]/[Cr] molar ratio was varied from 300 to 1500 (Table 2 , entries 8–10). The use of low loading of MAO (300 equiv.) led to a slightly decreases in the TOF [59,400 (mol ethylene) (mol Cr)−1⋅h−1] but still operating with high selectivity for production of α-olefins. Increasing the [Al]/[Cr] ratio from 300 to 1000 equiv. resulted in much higher TOF [235,300 (mol ethylene) (mol Cr)−1⋅h−1]. However, the best activity was achieved using 1500 equiv. of MAO [389,800 (mol ethylene) (mol Cr)−1⋅h−1] that is, 7-fold higher than that observed using 300 equiv. suggesting that excess of cocatalyst affords a higher number of catalytically active species. It is should be noted that the use of higher amounts of MAO not only positively affects the catalytic performance of this series of chromium precatalyst but also significantly decrease the amount of solids (1.8 – 2.3 wt%). At same time, a slightly improved selectivity for the α-C6 and α-C8 fractions were observed using 1000 equiv. of MAO (Table 2, entry 9). The combination of MAO with trimethylaluminum (TMA) (1:1) [[Al]/[Cr] = 500] slightly reduced the TOF [67,200 (mol ethylene) (mol Cr)−1⋅h−1] (compare entries 2 and 11). Moreover, presence of a large excess of TMA decreases the amount of PE (from 15.2 to 4.7 wt% of the total products) along with the production of a more balanced distribution of oligomers with enriched fractions in α-C4 (19.4 wt%) and α-C6 (20.7 wt%), and concomitant decreases in C12 + (24.8 wt%). On the other hand, the activation of Cr2 with trimethylaluminum (TMA)-depleted methylaluminoxane (DMAO) increases drastically the amount of polyethylene (67.2 wt%, entry 12) and the heavier fraction centered in C12 + (38.1 wt%). Thus, we speculate that the reducing power of DMAO is not sufficient to generate the divalent chromium species which are important intermediates species to afford a nonselective ethylene oligomerization catalyst. These results agree with those observed for similar pyrrolide-imine chromium complexes[46], and suggest that the presence of TMA in the reaction medium is a key requirement for producing mostly ethylene oligomerization active species. To gain further insight into the lifetime of active species, the productivity and product distribution were monitored versus time (5, 15 and 30 min). As can be seen in Fig. 6 , the total mass of products increased gradually within 30 min indicating that Cr2 shows good stability and had a minimal catalytic lifetime of 30 min. It is interesting to note that the oligomers/polymer ratio is nearly constant indicating that the nature of the active species did not vary over time. In addition, no significant variation in the selectivities for α-olefins (C4-C10) was observed over a 5–30 min period (66.7–71.2 wt.%), indicating that parallel chain isomerization processes are a minor pathway in these oligomerization reactions. The oligomerization reaction performed at lower ethylene pressure (5 atm) was found to favor the 1-C4, 1-C6 and 1-C8 selectivity while the catalytic activity decreases substantially due to the lower solubility of ethylene in toluene (entries 2 and 15). On elevating the oligomerization temperature from 80 °C to 100 °C, Cr2 showed lower activity [51,700 mol(ethylene) mol(Cr)–1⋅h–1] which reflects the partial decomposition of the active species at higher temperature; however this deactivation process is much lower when compared to analogous pyrrolide-imine chromium complex bearing pendant amine group[46], suggesting that the presence of pendant O-donor group confers better stability for Cr2. At higher temperature the oligomer distribution shifted slightly towards the formation of heavier olefins (C12 +: from 31.2 to 35.2 wt%). At same time, the product distribution (oligomers vs polymer) was almost unchanged indicating that both oligo- and polymerization catalytic species remains stable at 100ºC. To investigate the effect of preactivation time on the catalytic performance of Cr2, some oligomerization runs were carried out where the precatalyst was first dissolved and preactivated with 150 equiv of MAO in a Schlenk under ethylene atmosphere (1 bar) at room temperature for 15 min followed by adding this solution into the reactor Parr containing 350 equiv of MAO at 80 °C, and then oligomerization was carried out under 20 bar of ethylene. The oligomerization reactions using this preactivation protocol led to a significant improvement in the TOF (compare entries 2/17 and 13/18). For instance, the oligomerization run performed in 5 min resulted in catalytic activity of 300,000 mol(ethylene) mol(Cr)–1⋅h–1 that is 2-fold higher than one described in entry 13. Hence, the higher activities found using this preactivation methodology might be attributed to two main reasons: i) the better solubilization of Cr2 in toluene that preforms a higher amount of active species, and ii) the absence of induction oligomerization period. However, this process does not affect the selectivity and product distribution suggesting that in both cases the active species are the same. 3.3 Molecular modeling of active species The direct assignment of active species has been the subject of intensive research aiming to shed some light on the metal valence, active intermediate structure, and the transition state of ethylene insertion during the catalytic cycle in chromium-catalyzed ethylene oligo- and polymerization reactions. Among the different tools used to clarify these aspects, density functional theory (DFT) has successfully used by several research groups [42, 67-84]. Previous computational studies have suggested the formation of mono- or dinuclear chromium catalytic species with different oxidation states as responsible for production of oligomers and polymers. Thus, to explore the catalytically active species of chromium complexes supported by pyrrolide-imine ligands containing O- or S-pendant groups responsible for oligo- and polymerization reactions, Cr2 and Cr4 were selected and evaluated by DFT calculations. Initially, we executed DFT analysis presuming the formation of a mononuclear CrIII species. Thus, the alkylation reaction of Cr4 by MAO affords cationic Cr4-Me that bears one methyl group and two vacant sites generated by displacement of one THF molecule and the abstraction of one chloride ligand by MAO (Fig. 7 ). This intermediate species features a distorted tetrahedral geometry with Cr-C bond distance of 1.991 Å. The coordination of ethylene to the metal center in the perpendicular mode fashion related to the plane defined by the pyrrolide-imine ligand (Cr-Cethylene = 2.408 and 2.499 Å) is an exergonic process which favors the formation of the intermediate species Cr4-IM1 (ΔG = -8.6 kcal mol–1). The excess of ethylene in the reaction medium led to the insertion of this monomer into the Cr−Me bond in Cr4-IM1 to afford a more stable intermediate species Cr4-IM2 (ΔG= -12.5 kcal mol–1). Based on these DFT results we speculate that species Cr4-Me might be responsible for the ethylene polymerization. This result is in agreement with the experimental data (Table 1, entry 4), and those ones found for chromium complexes supported by SNN-tridentate ligands [85]. DFT calculations for Cr2 showed that the formation of the intermediate species Cr2-IM1 and Cr2-IM2 also are thermodynamically favorable by ΔG = -13.3 kcal mol–1 and ΔG = -17.0 kcal mol–1, respectively (Fig. S20). However, experimental results indicate that the activation of Cr2 with MAO led to a primarily oligomerization system with the amount of oligomers in the liquid fraction attaining 93.1 wt% of the total amount of products (entry 2). Therefore, we assume that other aspects such as kinetic factors and energy barrier are playing a significant role to generate mostly active species responsible for the oligomerization of ethylene. Considering the ability of Cr2 to produce mostly oligomers, we focused our efforts to obtain some evidence regarding to the nature of species responsible for the nonselective catalytic behavior. Thus, we executed a DFT calculations following the previously studies reported by Tromp and coworkers that involved the use of spectroscopic techniques (XAS, EPR and UV/VIS) and DFT calculations to gain more insight into the oxidation state and the structure of the active species in the [(R-SN(H)S-R)CrCl3] (R = C10H21) ethylene trimerization system [67]. It was demonstrated that the mechanism comprising a dinuclear cationic CrII/CrIII intermediates species would be responsible to afford a nonselective ethylene oligo- or polymerization catalyst. With this in mind, the DFT calculations were performed with the BP86/def2-TZVP level of theory envisioning the formation of a dinuclear cationic species (Cr2-C), as shown in Scheme 2 . The formation of mononuclear CrII species (Cr2-A and Cr2-B) can be rationalized via reaction of the Cr2 with free trimethylaluminum (TMA) contained within MAO. The minimum structures of Cr2-A and Cr2-B intermediates are shown in Fig. S21. The selected bond lengths and angles are presented in Table S2. The CrII/CrIII redox couple from a hypothesized cationic [(ONN)Cr(C2H4)]⁺ (Cr2-A) intermediate and a neutral square-planar [(ONN)CrCl} (Cr2-B) structure afforded the dinuclear species Cr2-C as presented in Fig. 8 . The bond lengths and angles of Cr2-C are in good agreement with those ones found for dinuclear [(SNS)Cr] complex[67], with Cr-C bond distances of 2.035 Å and the Cr···Cr distance of 3.657 Å (Table S2). Cr2-C is stable by the minimum structure obtained and its formation is feasible by the ΔG value of – 16.6 kcal mol⁻¹ (ΔE = – 39.4 kcal mol⁻¹). This value is lower than obtained for the [(SNS)Cr] complex with ΔG = – 10.8 kcal mol⁻¹ (ΔE = – 28 kcal mol⁻¹) [67]. Thus, we can infer that formation of Cr2-C is feasible, and it could be associated to primarily production of oligomers as observed experimentally. DFT calculations for Cr4 using the same approach as for Cr2 also resulted in a stable dinuclear species Cr4-C with ΔG reaction value of – 14.1 kcal mol⁻¹ (ΔE = – 33.3 kcal mol⁻¹) (Fig. S22). However, due to the very low amount of oligomer produced by Cr4/MAO catalytic system we consider that the dinuclear species Cr4-C is not the predominant catalytically active species in the reaction medium. The mononuclear species Cr4-Me and the binuclear species Cr4-C are formed by different pathways, so we cannot make a direct comparison between their reaction free energies and amount of these species in the reaction medium. On the basis of the results described above, we speculate that the activation of Cr2 and Cr4 with MAO might be generating two CrIII catalytic species (mono and binuclear) for the production of oligomers and polymer as shown in Scheme 3 . However, at this stage we are not able to determine the main factors that lead Cr2 to produce almost exclusively oligomers while Cr4 is a primarily polymerization system. Further DFT calculations are underway in our laboratories aiming to shed some light on the contrasting catalytic behavior of Cr2 and Cr4 and the results will be reported in due course. 4 Conclusions We have reported a new set of pyrrolide-imine chromium(III) catalysts bearing pendant O-, S- and N-donor groups. All complexes, upon activation with MAO, generated active species affording a full range oligomerization of ethylene along with the production of varied amounts of polymers. The electronic effects of the substituent at the ether/thioether groups have a significant impact on the catalytic performances of these Cr complexes. The presence of electron-withdrawing substituent (i.e., phenyl) at the pendant O- and S-donor moieties resulted in higher productivities and it can be associated to enhance of the Lewis acidity at the chromium metal center. By tunning the reactional conditions, higher TOF and higher selectivities for production of α-olefins were obtained using high MAO loading at 80 °C. This class of ligands confers good stability for the chromium catalysts with a minimal catalytic lifetime of 30 min. The oligomerization reactions using the preactivation protocol led to a significant improvement in the TOF along with high selectivity for production of α-olefins. In this case, the higher catalytic performance of the catalysts can be associated to the better solubilization of the chromium complexes in toluene as well as the absence of induction oligomerization period. The nature of the pendant group has a substantial effect on the product distribution. While chromium catalysts bearing pendant ether moieties (Cr1-Cr3) produce mostly oligomers, those based on the thioether groups (Cr4 and Cr5) led to primarily polymerization systems. DFT calculations suggested the presence of two different CrIII catalytic species, the mononuclear species responsible for production of polymer and one dinuclear species that have been ascribed for production of oligomers. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis and ethylene reactivity of a new set of chromium(III) complexes supported by pyrrolide-imine ligands bearing pendant O-, S- and N-donor groups [Cr{(C4H3N-2-CH=N)Z}(THF)Cl2] (Z = CH2Ph-2-OMe, Cr1; Z = Ph-2-OPh, Cr2; Z = Ph-2-OMe, Cr3; Z = Ph-2-SPh, Cr4; Z = Ph-2-SMe, Cr5; Z = CH2Py, Cr6; Z = C2H4Py, Cr7) are described. Activation of Cr1-Cr7 with MAO generates active systems affording a full range oligomerization of ethylene (C4-C12 +) with turnover frequencies (TOFs) in the range of 13,900–94,200 mol(ethylene)·mol(Cr)–1·h–1 along with production of a varied amount of polymer (6.9 - 91.5 wt.%). The nature of the pendant group has a significant impact on the catalytic performances of these Cr complexes. Particularly, catalytic precursors containing pendant O-donor groups (Cr1-Cr3) produce mostly oligomers (up to 89.0 wt%) while those bearing sulfur-base donor groups (Cr4 and Cr5) are primarily polymerization systems. DFT calculations suggested the presence of two different CrIII catalytic species, the mononuclear species responsible for production of polymer and one dinuclear species that have been ascribed for production of oligomers. By tunning the reactional conditions, higher TOF and higher selectivities for production of α-olefins were achieved. Notably, the use of high MAO loading (1500 equiv.) enhanced the activity of Cr2 [TOF = 389,800 (mol ethylene)⋅(mol Cr)−1⋅h−1] producing mostly oligomers (97.7 wt% of total products) with high selectivity for α-olefins (>95.5 wt.%).
coredata.dc:title: Oligo- and polymerization of ethylene by pyrrolide-imine chromium catalysts bearing pendant O-, S- and N-donor groups. Synthesis, characterization and DFT studies
